item.title: 4.4 Examples
item.description:
Intervals of Concavity In this section, we will work through examples that demonstrate how to determine the intervals where a function is concave up or concave down using the second derivative test. These examples will include polynomial, rational, trigonometric, and exponential functions. By the end of this section, students will:

  • Understand how to compute the second derivative of a function.
  • Use the second derivative test to classify intervals of concavity.
  • Solve problems involving various types of functions.

Example 1: Polynomial Function

Determine the intervals where the function \( f(x) = x^3 - 6x^2 + 9x + 2 \) is concave up or concave down.

item.title: 4.4 Practice
item.description:
Ex1. Determine the intervals where the function \( f(x) = x^3 - 4x^2 + 5x - 1 \) is concave up or concave down.

Solution Write the given function: \[ f(x) = x^3 - 4x^2 + 5x - 1 \] \[ f'(x) = 3x^2 - 8x + 5 \]\[ f''(x) = 6x - 8 \]\[ 6x - 8 = 0 \implies x = \frac{4}{3} \]
